hypotheses.title: Exploitation of BeyondTrust CVE-2026-1731 Leading to Ransomware Deployment
hypotheses.description: Attackers are actively exploiting the unauthenticated RCE vulnerability CVE-2026-1731 in BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products to deploy VShell, establish persistence, move laterally, and facilitate ransomware attacks. This vulnerability (CVSS 9.9) has been weaponized within hours of PoC release and is actively listed in CISA's KEV catalog.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTP requests to BeyondTrust RS/PRA management interfaces (typically ports 443/80), especially unauthenticated POST/GET requests with unusual payloads or paths
tools: Firewall logs
Proxy logs
WAF logs
Zeek (Bro) HTTP logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation events involving VShell.exe, WinSCP.exe, PsExec.exe, or other lateral movement tools launched from BeyondTrust service accounts or elevated contexts
tools: EDR (CrowdStrike, SentinelOne), Sysmon, Windows Event Logs (4688, 1)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Unusual privilege escalation events (e.g., elevation to SYSTEM or admin from non-admin accounts) on systems hosting BeyondTrust components
tools: SIEM (Splunk, Sentinel), Active Directory audit logs, LAPS logs

hunting_tactics.description: Search for suspicious HTTP requests to BeyondTrust management interfaces that lack authentication headers or contain malformed credentials.
sample_queries: index=netflow OR index=proxy host="*beyondtrust*" OR url="*/admin/*" OR url="*/api/*" status_code=200 (method=POST OR method=GET) (user="-" OR user="anonymous" OR user="null")

index=firewall src_ip=* dst_port=443 dst_host=*beyondtrust* OR dst_host=*rs.* OR dst_host=*pra.* (http_method=POST OR http_method=GET) (http_user_agent="*" AND http_user_agent!="*Mozilla*" AND http_user_agent!="*Chrome*" AND http_user_agent!="*Safari*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Requests to /admin, /api/v1, /rpc, /ws, or /settings endpoints from non-browser user agents or without authentication; repeated failed login attempts followed by success; connections from high-risk geolocations (e.g., Russia, China, North Korea)

hunting_tactics.description: Detect deployment of VShell or other tools commonly used post-exploitation to maintain access and pivot.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name="VShell.exe" OR process_name="WinSCP.exe" OR process_name="psexec.exe" OR process_name="psexec64.exe") (parent_process_name="*rs.exe" OR parent_process_name="*pra.exe" OR parent_process_name="*beyondtrust*" OR parent_process_path="*\Program Files\BeyondTrust*")
index=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\VShell.exe" OR Image="*\WinSCP.exe") (ParentImage="*\RS.exe" OR ParentImage="*\PRA.exe" OR ParentImage="*\BeyondTrust*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Execution of VShell, WinSCP, or PsExec from BeyondTrust service processes; unusual child processes spawned by BeyondTrust binaries; execution from non-standard directories (e.g., %TEMP%, AppData\Local\Temp)

network_patterns: Connections to BeyondTrust management ports (e.g., 443, 80, 8080) from non-internal IP ranges
other_indicators: Unexpected outbound connections from BeyondTrust service accounts
Logon events (4624) with Logon Type 3 from BeyondTrust service accounts to other internal hosts
Unusual outbound traffic to known C2 infrastructure (e.g., Telegram, Discord webhooks)

recommended_actions: Isolate affected BeyondTrust systems immediately
Verify patch status: CVE-2026-1731 was patched in BeyondTrust updates released February 6–14, 2026
Review logs for lateral movement to domain controllers or high-value servers
Check for persistence mechanisms (scheduled tasks, registry run keys, services) created by attackers
Conduct memory analysis on compromised BeyondTrust hosts for VShell artifacts

hypotheses.title: ClickFix Social Engineering Campaigns Delivering MIMICRAT, XWorm, and MacSync via Fake CAPTCHA or AI Guides
hypotheses.description: ClickFix threat actors are evolving their social engineering tactics to trick users into executing malicious PowerShell, nslookup, or JavaScript commands—often via fake CAPTCHA challenges, AI-generated guides (e.g., Claude, Gemini), or hijacked Google Ads. These campaigns deliver infostealers (XWorm 7.2, MIMICRAT, MacSync), crypto stealers, and RATs, with recent variants using DNS tunneling and steganography to evade detection.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1564.001 - Hide Artifacts: Hidden Files and Directories

data_sources_needed.specific_data: PowerShell command-line logs (EventID 4104), nslookup execution with custom DNS queries, browser process spawning unusual child processes (e.g., cmd.exe, powershell.exe)
tools: Sysmon (EventID 1, 3, 13), PowerShell script block logging, EDR, Windows Event Logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS queries with encoded payloads in TXT/CNAME records, HTTP requests to Pastebin/GitHub hosting malicious scripts, connections to known C2 domains (e.g., voidlink[.]xyz, ghosttapped[.]com)
tools: DNS logs (e.g., BIND, Cisco Umbrella), Proxy logs, Zeek DNS/HTTP logs, SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Phishing emails with fake CAPTCHA links, malicious PDFs, or AI-generated instructions; URLs pointing to compromised or typosquatted domains
tools: Email security gateways (e.g., Mimecast, Proofpoint), SIEM, URL reputation services

hunting_tactics.description: Detect use of nslookup to exfiltrate data or retrieve payloads via DNS TXT records—a novel ClickFix variant observed in February 2026.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\system32\nslookup.exe" OR Image="*\syswow64\nslookup.exe") (CommandLine="*" AND CommandLine!="*google.com*" AND CommandLine!="*microsoft.com*" AND CommandLine!="*cloudflare.com*")
index=endpoint process_name=nslookup.exe (command_line=*"*"* OR command_line=*TXT* OR command_line=*CNAME*) | stats count by host, user, command_line | where count > 1
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup.exe executed from non-system contexts (e.g., via PowerShell, cmd.exe, or browser); queries for suspicious domains (e.g., *.pastebin[.]com, *.github[.]io, *.discord[.]com); long or base64-encoded DNS queries

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: ClickFix JavaScript via Pastebin or Google Groups
hunting_tactics.description: Search for JavaScript execution triggered by malicious Pastebin comments or Google Groups posts used to hijack crypto swaps or steal credentials.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name="*chrome.exe" OR process_name="*msedge.exe" OR process_name="*firefox.exe") (parent_process_name="*chrome.exe" OR parent_process_name="*msedge.exe") (command_line="*eval(" OR command_line="*Function(" OR command_line="*atob(" OR command_line="*btoa(")

index=sentinel (EventID=4104) (ScriptBlockText=*eval* OR ScriptBlockText=*atob* OR ScriptBlockText=*btoa*) (ScriptBlockText=*pastebin* OR ScriptBlockText=*google[.]groups* OR ScriptBlockText=*clickfix*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: JavaScript execution containing base64-decoded payloads; references to pastebin[.]com, raw.githubusercontent[.]com, or discord[.]com in script blocks; suspicious crypto swap or MetaMask-related keywords

hunting_tactics.description: Detect Pulsar RAT or XWorm 7.2 delivered via malicious Excel or PNG files using steganography.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name="*excel.exe" OR process_name="*winword.exe" OR process_name="*cmd.exe") (parent_process_name="*excel.exe" OR parent_process_name="*winword.exe") (command_line="*rundll32*" OR command_line="*regsvr32*" OR command_line="*mshta*")

index=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\rundll32.exe" OR Image="*\regsvr32.exe" OR Image="*\mshta.exe") (ParentImage="*\excel.exe" OR ParentImage="*\winword.exe") (CommandLine="*" AND CommandLine!="*C:\Program Files*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Rundll32/regsvr32/mshta execution from Excel/Word; suspicious command lines referencing .dll, .js, .vbs; execution from %TEMP%, AppData, or user directories

network_patterns: DNS TXT queries with base64-encoded payloads
HTTP GET requests to Pastebin/GitHub with large response bodies (>10KB)
Outbound connections to Telegram/Discord webhooks (e.g., discordapp[.]com/api/webhooks)
other_indicators: Processes spawning from user-writable directories (e.g., %TEMP%, Downloads)
Unusual outbound traffic from endpoints without installed browsers

recommended_actions: Block known malicious domains (e.g., pastebin[.]com variants, voidlink[.]xyz) at DNS/proxy level
Disable nslookup.exe from non-admin contexts via AppLocker or EDR policies
Enable PowerShell script block logging and AMSI to detect obfuscated commands
Review Google Ads and social media for hijacked campaigns impersonating Microsoft or AI tools
Hunt for XWorm/MIMICRAT artifacts in memory (e.g., process injection, credential harvesting)

hypotheses.title: AI-Driven FortiGate Compromise via Exposed Management Interfaces and Weak Credentials
hypotheses.description: A Russian-speaking financially motivated threat actor used commercial generative AI tools to compromise over 600 FortiGate firewalls across 55 countries in early 2026. The actor did not exploit software vulnerabilities but abused exposed management ports (e.g., 443, 8443) and weak single-factor credentials (e.g., admin/admin, default passwords) to gain access, highlighting the risk of AI-augmented credential stuffing and reconnaissance.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1565.001 - Data Manipulation: Stored Data Manipulation

data_sources_needed.specific_data: FortiGate management interface access logs (HTTPS/HTTP), failed login attempts, unusual geographic access patterns, outbound connections to AWS/GCP/Azure services
tools: FortiAnalyzer/FortiSIEM
Firewall logs
NetFlow/sFlow
Zeek (FortiGate logs)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Changes to firewall configuration (e.g., new routes, policies, SSH keys), unexpected outbound connections from FortiGate to cloud storage or C2 infrastructure
tools: FortiEDR
Endpoint logs
Configuration management databases (CMDB)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: AWS/GCP/Azure API calls from compromised FortiGate (e.g., S3 uploads, EC2 launches), unusual data exfiltration to cloud storage
tools: CloudTrail, Cloud Audit Logs, AWS GuardDuty, Azure Defender for Cloud

hunting_tactics.description: Detect unauthorized access to FortiGate management interfaces using AI-augmented credential stuffing.
sample_queries: index=fortinet (event_type="login" OR event_type="auth") (status="failure" OR status="success") (user="admin" OR user="root" OR user="*" OR user="") | stats count by src_ip, user, status | where count > 5
index=fortinet (event_type="config_change" OR event_type="policy_update") (src_ip!="10.*" AND src_ip!="192.168.*" AND src_ip!="172.16.*") | stats count by src_ip, dst_ip, event_type | where count > 1
hunting_tactics.look_for: Multiple failed logins followed by success from external IPs; access from high-risk geolocations (e.g., Russia, Ukraine, China); configuration changes initiated from non-internal IPs

hunting_tactics.description: Search for data exfiltration from FortiGate to cloud services (e.g., AWS S3, Azure Blob) using AI tools for obfuscation.
sample_queries: index=aws_cloudtrail (eventName="PutObject" OR eventName="GetObject") (sourceIPAddress="*fortigate*" OR sourceIPAddress="*firewall*") (bucketName="*s3*" OR bucketName="*storage*")

index=fortinet (event_type="traffic" OR event_type="log_upload") (dst_ip="*169.254.*" OR dst_ip="*100.64.*" OR dst_ip="*172.16.*" OR dst_ip="*192.168.*") | stats count by src_ip, dst_ip, dst_port | where dst_port=443 AND count > 100
hunting_tactics.look_for: Large outbound data transfers to cloud storage (e.g., AWS S3, Azure Blob) from FortiGate IPs; connections to known AI/ML service endpoints (e.g., api.openai[.]com, gemini[.]google[.]com) from firewall devices

network_patterns: Outbound HTTPS (443) from FortiGate to cloud storage or AI services
other_indicators: Changes to FortiGate SSH keys or admin accounts
New firewall policies allowing outbound traffic to cloud services
Unexpected log uploads to cloud storage (e.g., /var/log/fortigate/*)

recommended_actions: Audit all FortiGate instances for exposed management interfaces (ports 443, 8443, 22) and enforce MFA
Review firewall logs for configuration changes initiated from external IPs
Block outbound traffic from firewalls to AI services and cloud storage unless explicitly required
Hunt for AI-generated traffic patterns (e.g., repeated API calls with similar payloads)
Verify FortiOS patch status: CVE-2026-1731 and related flaws were patched in February 2026

hypotheses.title: Supply Chain Compromise of Open Source Tools (npm, VS Code, Notepad++) Leading to OpenClaw, StealC, and OpenClaw AI Agent Theft
hypotheses.description: Multiple supply chain attacks compromised npm packages (e.g., Cline CLI, graphalgo), VS Code extensions, and Notepad++ to deliver malware (OpenClaw, StealC, Pulsar RAT, XWorm). Attackers stole npm publish tokens or compromised hosting infrastructure to inject malicious code. Notably, infostealers are now targeting OpenClaw AI agent configuration files, indicating a shift toward stealing AI identity and secrets.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution from npm, VS Code, or Notepad++ directories; unusual child processes (e.g., python, node, powershell) spawned by development tools
tools: Sysmon, EDR, npm audit logs, VS Code extension logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Outbound connections to npm registry, GitHub, or cloud services from development machines; DNS queries for typosquatted domains (e.g., notepad-plus-plus[.]org vs notepad-plus-plus[.]com)
tools: DNS logs, Proxy logs, Zeek, SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Unusual API key or token usage (e.g., GitHub, npm, AWS) from developer accounts; access to OpenClaw configuration files
tools: Git logs, CI/CD pipeline logs, secrets management tools (e.g., HashiCorp Vault)

hunting_tactics.description: Detect installation of typosquatted or compromised npm packages (e.g., graphalgo, OpenClaw, StealC) used in supply chain attacks.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name="*npm*" OR process_name="*node*") (command_line="*install*" AND command_line!="*--save-dev*" AND command_line!="*--save*" AND command_line!="*package.json*")
index=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\npm.exe" OR Image="*\node.exe") (CommandLine="*install*" AND CommandLine=*graphalgo* OR CommandLine=*cline* OR CommandLine=*stealc* OR CommandLine=*openclaw*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: npm/node execution from non-standard directories (e.g., %TEMP%, AppData\Local\Temp); installation of packages with suspicious names (e.g., graphalgo, openclaw-ai, stealc-core); child processes spawning from npm (e.g., python, powershell)

hunting_tactics.description: Search for infostealer activity targeting OpenClaw configuration files (e.g., Clawdbot, Moltbot) containing API keys, tokens, and secrets.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name="*infostealer*" OR process_name="*lumma*" OR process_name="*amos*" OR process_name="*arkanix*") (command_line="*openclaw*" OR command_line="*clawdbot*" OR command_line="*moltbot*")

index=sysmon EventID=11 (Image="*\infostealer.exe" OR Image="*\lumma.exe") (TargetFilename="*openclaw*" OR TargetFilename="*clawdbot*" OR TargetFilename="*moltbot*" OR TargetFilename="*config.json*" OR TargetFilename="*secrets.json*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: File access to openclaw/, clawdbot/, moltbot/ directories; exfiltration of config.json, secrets.json, or identity.json files; execution of infostealers from developer machines

hunting_tactics.description: Detect malicious VS Code extensions (e.g., Live Server, Code Runner) with vulnerabilities CVE-2025-65715/6/7 used to steal files or execute code.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name="*code.exe" OR process_name="*cursor.exe" OR process_name="*windsurf*") (command_line="*--extensions-dir*" OR command_line="*--user-data-dir*")
index=sysmon EventID=1 (Image="*\Code.exe" OR Image="*\Cursor.exe") (CommandLine="*--install-extension*" AND CommandLine=*jkh* OR CommandLine=*formulahendry* OR CommandLine=*ritwickdey*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Installation of extensions with known malicious IDs (e.g., jkphinfhmfkckkcnifhjiplhfoiefffl); execution of code from extension directories (e.g., .vscode/extensions/*); suspicious outbound connections from code.exe

network_patterns: Outbound HTTPS to npm registry, GitHub, or cloud storage from dev machines
DNS queries for typosquatted domains (e.g., notepad-plus-plus[.]com, cline[.]xyz)
Connections to Telegram/Discord from developer endpoints
other_indicators: Unusual API key usage from developer accounts (e.g., GitHub, npm, AWS)
Execution of python/node from non-standard directories

recommended_actions: Audit npm, VS Code, and Notepad++ logs for typosquatted or compromised packages
Enable npm audit and GitHub Dependabot alerts for known vulnerabilities
Hunt for OpenClaw configuration files (e.g., openclaw.json, clawdbot.json) and exfiltration attempts
Review CI/CD pipelines for unauthorized package uploads or token theft
Block outbound traffic from developer machines to AI services unless explicitly allowed

hypotheses.title: PromptSpy Android Malware Abusing Gemini AI for Persistence and Surveillance
hypotheses.description: PromptSpy is the first known Android malware to abuse Google’s Gemini AI at runtime to maintain persistence and adapt to different devices. It uses Gemini to analyze on-screen elements, block uninstallation attempts, and ensure the malware remains pinned in the recent apps list, enabling advanced spying features like lockscreen data capture, screen recording, and screenshot collection.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.007 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Android Shell
T1564.008 - Hide Artifacts: AI Model Obfuscation
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Android system logs (logcat), process execution from suspicious directories (e.g., /data/data/com.google.android.gms), Gemini API calls from non-Google apps
tools: Android Debug Bridge (ADB), Mobile EDR (e.g., SentinelOne Mobile), Android logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS connections to Gemini API endpoints (e.g., gemini.google.com, aistudio.google.com) from Android devices
tools: Mobile proxy logs (e.g., Charles, Burp), Zeek (HTTP logs), Mobile SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Unusual app permissions (e.g., DRAW_OVERLAY, FOREGROUND_SERVICE, READ_LOGS) granted to suspicious apps
tools: MDM (e.g., Intune, Jamf), Android Enterprise logs, Google Play Console

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Gemini API Abuse by Non-Google Apps
hunting_tactics.description: Detect Android apps making Gemini API calls, which is indicative of PromptSpy or similar AI-assisted malware.
sample_queries: index=android (package_name!="com.google.android.apps.genie.geniewidget" AND package_name!="com.google.android.gm" AND package_name!="com.google.android.apps.dynamite") (command_line="*gemini*" OR command_line="*aistudio.google.com*" OR command_line="*generativelanguage.googleapis.com*")

index=zeek (http_host="gemini.google.com" OR http_host="aistudio.google.com" OR http_host="generativelanguage.googleapis.com") (user_agent!="*Mozilla*" AND user_agent!="*Chrome*" AND user_agent!="*GSA*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: HTTPS connections to gemini.google.com, aistudio.google.com, or generativelanguage.googleapis.com from non-Google apps; logcat entries with 'Gemini' or 'AI' keywords; unusual foreground service usage (e.g., FOREGROUND_SERVICE type 1)

hunting_tactics.description: Search for apps using DRAW_OVERLAY or FOREGROUND_SERVICE to maintain persistence and evade uninstallation.
sample_queries: index=android (event_type="permission_grant" OR event_type="app_install") (package_name=* AND permission="android.permission.SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW" OR permission="android.permission.FOREGROUND_SERVICE")
index=adb (command="dumpsys activity services" AND output="*PromptSpy*" OR output="*GeminiService*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Apps with SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW or FOREGROUND_SERVICE permissions; services named PromptSpyService, GeminiService, or similar; apps installed from non-Play Store sources (e.g., APK files from Telegram, fake IPTV apps)

network_patterns: HTTPS to gemini.google.com from Android devices
Outbound connections to Telegram/Discord from Android devices
other_indicators: Apps installed from unknown sources (e.g., APK files)
Unusual screen recording or screenshot activity (e.g., ScreenCapture, MediaProjection)

recommended_actions: Audit Android devices for apps with SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW or FOREGROUND_SERVICE permissions
Block outbound HTTPS to gemini.google.com from corporate Android devices
Hunt for PromptSpy APKs installed from non-Play Store sources
Review logcat for Gemini API calls (e.g., 'Gemini', 'AI', 'prompt')
Deploy mobile EDR solutions to detect AI-assisted malware

unique_mitre_techniques: T1059.007 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Android Shell
T1565.001 - Data Manipulation: Stored Data Manipulation
T1564.008 - Hide Artifacts: AI Model Obfuscation
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files
T1564.001 - Hide Artifacts: Hidden Files and Directories
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
